conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the flow of liquid through the depicted channels and baffles.
The image shows several colored channels labeled A, B, C, D, and E, each with arrows indicating the direction of flow.
The task is to predict which container (D or E) the liquid will flow into after passing through the baffles labeled A, B, and C.
The baffles are labeled A, B, and C.
The arrows indicate the direction of the liquid flow.
From point A, the arrow points towards point D.

premise: From point A, the arrow points towards point D.
conclusion: The liquid from A will flow into D.

premise: Streams from A and B both land on the green baffle, they merge and flow to the left.
conclusion: The combined flow from A and B will split at the bottom, with part entering container D on the left.

premise: The stream from C falls on the right edge of the green baffle and is deflected to the right.
conclusion: The stream from C will continue along its own baffle and fall into container E.

premise: Streams from A and B merge on the slanted cyan baffle; the combined flow then splits at the bottom.
conclusion: Part of the combined flow from A and B will enter container E on the right.

premise: The combined flow from A and B ends up in container D with a small portion of C joining; conversely, container E receives most of the flow from C with a small portion from A and B.
conclusion: Most of the combined flow from A and B ends up in container D with a small portion of C joining; conversely, container E receives most of the flow from C with a small portion from A and B.
